bodyText: The Eastern Trophy Room contains a collection of reproduction civil war flags and a mural which maps the southern theater of the civil war.

title: General Grant National Memorial

images.altText: Black and white of large building with dome on top with grass in front
images.title: Grant's Tomb
images.caption: Grant's Tomb

relatedParks.fullName: Frederick Law Olmsted National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Frederick Law Olmsted

bodyText:
Before Ulysses S. Grant passed away, he requested that he be buried either at West Point, in the Illinois town of Galena he once called home, or New York City. After New York City was chosen as a burial site, the next task would be deciding where in the ever-expanding city.

While many favored Central Park, a location at Riverside Park was chosen after Frederick Law Olmsted’s close acquaintance Samuel Parsons Jr. convinced Grant’s widow Julia that the Hudson River setting, with its sweeping panoramic views, was superior.

Shortly after the burial, anxiety began to grow regarding the site of Grant’s Tomb, that it was inappropriate and would lend an unfortunate funerary air to this section of Riverside Park, which had been considered a gala promenade. Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux were particularly concerned.

Nestled within the picturesque landscape of Riverside Park, Grant’s Tomb was designed to be approached by rail, water, carriage, and by foot. Grant’s Tomb is located atop one of the highest points along Riverside Drive, with surrounding formal walkways and parklands designed by Parsons and Vaux.

To ease Olmsted and Vaux’s concerns, Vaux and Parsons proposed that the grounds of Grant’s Tomb be separated from the rest of Riverside Park with a newly cut road, which was done, ensuring Grant’s Tomb and Riverside Park could coexist in Olmsted’s vision of providing open park space unobstructed by the outside world.

title: Grant's Tomb
listingDescription: Grant's Tomb is a reminder of how different a figure can appear in the light of current events versus the long view of history. In the summer of 1864, the press reviled "Butcher Grant," and his presidency remains notorious for corruption. A decade after his death the largest public fundraising to that point in American history brought in $600,000 for his tomb and a million people attended its dedication in 1897.

images.altText: Visitors attend Civil War program with Grant's Tomb in the background.
images.title: Visitors attend Civil War program with Grant's Tomb in the background.
images.description: Civil War presentation at Grant's Tomb
images.caption: Civil War presentation at Grant's Tomb

bodyText:
This memorial to Ulysses S. Grant--victorious Union commander of the Civil War--includes the tombs of General Grant and his wife, Julia Dent Grant. A West Point graduate, Grant served in the Mexican War and at various frontier posts before rapidly rising through the ranks during the Civil War. Grant's tenacity and boldness led to victories in the Battles of Vicksburg and Chattanooga and Robert E. Lee's surrender at Appomattox. Scenes of these events are depicted in mosaics in the tomb. In 1866, Congress awarded Grant his fourth star, making him the first full General of the Armies.

A grateful nation elected Grant to serve as President of the United States twice, in 1868 and 1872. Grant's accomplishments include signing the act that established the first national park, Yellowstone, on March 1, 1872. After his presidency, Grant settled in New York City. He died of throat cancer on July 23, 1885 in Mount McGregor, New York and was laid to rest in New York City on August 8.

Approximately 90,000 people from around the world donated over $600,000 towards the construction of Grant's Tomb. This was the largest public fundraising effort ever at that time. Designed by architect John Duncan, the granite and marble structure was completed in 1897 and remains the largest mausoleum in North America. Over one million people attended the parade and dedication ceremony of Grant's Tomb on April 27, 1897.

quickFacts.value: The burial place of General Grant, and the largest tomb in North America

quickFacts.name: Designation

title: Mausoleum for Ulysses S Grant
listingDescription: The final resting place of American Civil War General and President Ulysses S. Grant and his wife, Julia Dent Grant, is the largest mausoleum in North America. It testifies to a people’s gratitude for the man who ended the bloodiest conflict in American history as Commanding General of the Union Army and then, as the 18th President of the United States, strove to heal a nation after a civil war and make rights for all citizens a reality.

images.altText: front of tomb with dome, columns, flags and people walking on broad steps
images.title: Grants Tomb with Banners and Buntings
images.caption: Banners and Buntings adorn the Mausoleum for Ulysses S. Grant during summer months

bodyText: Also known as Grants Tomb by locals, the mausoleum at General Grant National Memorial is the final resting place for American Civil War Union General and 18th U.S. President Ulysses S. Grant and his wife Julia Dent Grant. Each of thier remains lie within two 8 1/2 ton red Montello Granite Sarcophogi in the center of the round crypt watched over by five busts of Union generals that served under Grant: Sherman, McPherson, Ord, Thomas, and Sheridan. Architect John H. Duncan, who was selected by the Grant Monument Association in 1890, was inspired in part by Napolean's Tomb in Les Invalides, France as well as Helicarnassus in Ancient Greece.
audioDescription: The Square base of the tomb is surmounted with a round rotunda, capped by a stepped, conical shaped roof. The entirety of the exterior is light grey granite stone, with some carved ornaments in areas. Broad steps lead to the front of the structure that has 5 large, heavy fluted Greek columns supporting a thick stone portico. Behind the columns are heavy bronze doors 17 feet high. The front of the tomb has broad stairs with two granite carved eagle statues on either side. A wide open stone plaza fills the space in front of the monumental tomb.
passportStampLocationDescription: Stamp is identical in Mausoleum and Visitor Center. If buildings are closed, contact park at gegr_info@nps.gov for stamp.

passportStampImages.altText: Stamp: General Grant National Memorial, New York, NY OCT 25 2020

title: The Crypt in Grant's Tomb

images.altText: Half the stone path way around one of the Grant's sarcophogai
images.title: The Crypt at Grant's Mausoleum
images.caption: The Crypt

bodyText: The Crypt level contains the sarcophogai of both Ulysses and Julia Grant. Around the edge of the circle are 5 statues of other Civil War generals.
audioDescription: A stone circular pathway surrounding the large stone sarcophagi on a raised stone platform in the center of the room.

title: The Rotunda of Grant's Tomb

images.altText: White dome towers high above the image
images.title: The Inner Dome of Grant's Mausoleum
images.caption: The inner dome of the Mausoleum was heavily inspired by the Pantheon in Rome

bodyText: The Main Rotunda at General Grant National Memorial is the largest space inside the Mausoleum. The soaring ceiling rises more than 100 feet in to the air to a dome that covers the decorated room. The sunken crypt below the central viewing gallery contains the sarcophogai of Ulysses S Grant and his wife Julia D Grant.
audioDescription: A large marble room with a ceiling that soars a hundred feet up to a dome that caps the building. A marble ledge forms a circle in the center of the room and on the walls are colorful mosaics which depict Civil War scenes.

title: Western Trophy Room

images.altText: Stone door way framing a collection of Flags
images.title: Western Trophy Room
images.caption: The western trophy houses half of the replica flag collection

bodyText: The Western Trophy room houses several replica Civil War flags as well as a mural depicting the northern theater of the Civil War.
audioDescription: A small circular room surrounding an ornate metal and glass case housing colorful civil war flags. The wall has a mural which depicts the northern battles of the Civil War.
